awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Machine Learning Approaches for Supply Chain Decision-Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Supply chain refers to the system that moves goods from where they are produced to where they are consumed. This system includes manufacturing, assembly, warehousing, transportation, and retailing processes. This project will study how to improve efficiency and robustness of the supply chain by using novel machine learning techniques to control the supply chain automatically. The project specifically focuses on the development of decision-making strategies to deal with uncertainties and correct disruptions in the supply chain system. In collaboration with an industrial partner, Siemens, the project will focus on a real supply chain application related to the production and distribution of radiopharmaceuticals (an important component in health diagnostics). The advancements in supply chain and machine learning resulting from this project have potential to benefit a wide range of industries.   

This project studies a new approach for using machine learning (ML) as a tool for optimizing, analyzing and controlling supply chains. Current approach to supply chain operations makes assumptions about statistical distributions of uncertain factors in supply chain and uses predictive techniques or forecasts to estimate the few parameters required to characterize these distributions. These estimated distributions are then used in the analysis and control of the supply chain. This project has a novel approach of combining the data-analysis and supply-chain optimization stages into a single ML algorithm.  The project focuses on two main classes of supply chain problems: production and distribution of radiopharmaceuticals (a core problem for the industrial partner, Siemens), and early warnings and corrective actions for stochastic supply chains. In addition, the project will make methodological contributions to the theory and implementation of ML algorithms, including new loss functions, techniques for using deep learning as a preprocessing step for reinforcement learning, adaptive strategies to handle non-stationary data, and improved initialization methods for ML. The tools and concepts to be develop will be generalizable more broadly, both within and beyond supply chain.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the use of machine learning (ML) to improve the state-of-the-art approaches in a supply chain, both in theory and practice. With our industry partner, Siemens Corporation, Corporate Technology (SC CT), we developed models for optimizing supply chains using reinforcement learning (RL), a type of ML. These models included models for vehicle routing, scheduling, and inventory optimization. They were designed with Siemens' interest in radiopharmaceuticals in mind, but the models and algorithms we developed are applicable much more broadly. 

Intellectual Merit: We developed RL models for optimizing supply chains. Most ML models for supply chains that have been developed to date use ML for predictive analytics, i.e., for forecasting; those predictive models then provide inputs to other (e.g., optimization) models. In contrast, our models use ML for prescriptive analytics, i.e., for making decisions directly, avoiding the need for two separate steps (forecasting + optimization). We find that this approach is more accurate than the traditional approach.

Our work has made contributions to how we understand supply chains. For example, we showed that the classical vehicle routing problem (VRP) can be efficiently solved using RL, and that an RL model trained on one type of data can often be applied to new instances without re-training. We also showed that the best-known inventory policy for a particular type of inventory system (which derives from the "beer game," a well-known educational activity for supply chain management) is actually not optimal in realistic settings. We know this because the RL agent that we developed for this setting outperforms the current best-known policy. This motivates future research to investigate what policy types are optimal, and to learn lessons from how the RL optimizes inventory.

At the same time, our work has also made contributions to the study of RL itself. We investigated RL formulations with constrains and also proposed a corrective RL framework that aims to develop policy that are not very different from policies currently used by humans. 

Broader Impact: We disseminated our results in highly selective conferences (e.g., NeurIPS) and journals (e.g., Manufacturing & Service Operations Management and IISE Transactions). We presented results from this project specifically, and topics related to ML and supply chain management more broadly, at a range of events, including industry-oriented conferences and lectures, academic-oriented conferences and seminars, and in public-facing outlets. We also conducted outreach activities including teaching robotics to elementary school students and discussing ML and supply chain management to middle school girls interested in STEM.
